alt_statements.statement: I think there should be more trash cans everywhere and big, colorful signs that remind people to throw their garbage away, because God wants us to take care of His creation. Grown-ups should get tickets if they litter on purpose, but kids could have to help clean up so they learn not to do it again. Schools and churches could also have clean-up days so we all feel proud of keeping our town neat.

I think the best way to stop littering is to teach kids and adults why it’s wrong, like how it hurts animals and makes our neighborhoods look bad, and to show good examples at school and church. There should be plenty of trash and recycling cans around, with clear signs, and maybe small fines or having to do community clean-ups if someone keeps littering. I’d also like more community clean-up days where families work together, so everyone feels responsible for keeping our parks and streets clean.

As someone who’s spent a life caring for people’s health, I see clean public spaces as part of basic community well-being, so we need strong anti-littering policies that actually get enforced, not just signs people ignore. Cities should combine meaningful fines with plenty of trash and recycling bins, public education in schools and community centers, and programs that pay or reward folks—especially low-income and disabled residents—for helping with cleanups. I also support holding corporations responsible for excess packaging and waste, because everyday people shouldn’t shoulder all the blame while big companies profit.

As someone who spends a lot of time out and about and cares about my community, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of strict enforcement and real investment in public trash and recycling bins, especially in lower-income and historically neglected neighborhoods. Fines should be meaningful and actually enforced, but cities also need to make it easy and normal to do the right thing through education in schools, community clean-up events, and campaigns that show pride in keeping our spaces clean. As a Democrat and a Catholic, I see caring for the environment and our shared spaces as both a social responsibility and a moral duty, not just a personal preference.

Como alguien que pasa muchas horas trabajando de cara al público, me duele ver cómo la gente tira basura en las calles y en los parques que compartimos como comunidad. Creo que deben existir multas claras y aplicarse de verdad a quienes ensucian, pero también es importante poner suficientes botes de basura y reciclaje visibles, y educar desde las escuelas y las iglesias sobre el cuidado de lo que Dios nos ha dado. Las campañas de limpieza organizadas por el barrio y las iglesias también ayudan a que la gente sienta orgullo por su entorno y se piense dos veces antes de tirar algo al suelo.

As someone who delivers packages all over the city and spends weekends at the park with my kids, I see how much litter can build up and how it hurts our neighborhoods. I think the best policies mix real consequences, like fines and community service for littering, with plenty of trash and recycling bins, clear signs, and public education in both English and Spanish. If we also invest in local cleanup programs that involve families, churches, and schools, people feel more ownership and pride in keeping our streets clean. Everyone should have an equal chance to live in a clean, safe community, no matter the neighborhood.

Working in a hospital, I see every day how small choices add up to big impacts on our environment and public health, so I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of clear rules, visible trash and recycling bins, and consistent fines that are actually enforced. Just as important, though, is education—especially for kids and in community spaces—so people understand how litter affects neighborhoods, waterways, and wildlife. When people feel responsible for their shared spaces and see that others care too, they’re a lot less likely to treat the environment like a dumping ground.

As someone who spends a lot of time reading environmental health literature, I’m convinced the most effective anti-litter policies combine behaviorally informed design with clear consequences. That means plentiful, well-placed bins and recycling options; clean, well-maintained public spaces (people are less likely to litter in environments that already look cared for); and consistent fines that are actually enforced. Public education campaigns grounded in evidence—especially those that frame littering as harming our shared community health—can shift norms more sustainably than punishment alone. If we treat our streets and parks like shared laboratories whose “data” is our collective well-being, we’ll invest in keeping them clean.

As someone who spends a lot of time outdoors sketching and finding inspiration in parks and city streets, it breaks my heart to see trash scattered where beauty should be. I think we need a mix of practical steps—like plenty of accessible trash and recycling bins, regular clean-up crews, and meaningful fines for repeat offenders—along with public art and education campaigns that make people feel proud of keeping shared spaces clean. I’d especially love to see community-led projects and school programs that involve kids in caring for their neighborhoods, because when people feel a sense of ownership and connection, they’re far less likely to litter in the first place.

As someone who loves taking my family hiking and camping, it really bothers me to see trails and parks cluttered with trash, so I think strong anti-littering policies are important. The best approach combines clear, consistently enforced fines with plenty of trash and recycling bins, plus public education that emphasizes personal responsibility and respect for shared spaces. I’d also support community clean-up events and volunteer programs, because when people help care for their parks and streets, they’re less likely to treat them like a dumping ground.

As someone who spends long hours working to protect this country, it bothers me to see our own communities treated carelessly. The best way to prevent littering is a mix of strong enforcement—real fines that are actually applied—and straightforward public education, especially for kids, about personal responsibility and respect for shared spaces. I’d also support more trash and recycling bins in high-traffic areas, but ultimately people need to be held accountable for their actions.

As someone who spends my free time walking in parks and enjoying quiet, natural spaces, I believe strong anti-littering policies are essential, but they have to be practical and consistently enforced. Clear signage, plenty of visible trash and recycling bins, and meaningful fines for repeat offenders strike the right balance between personal responsibility and community standards. I’d also like to see businesses held accountable for managing waste around their properties, since a lot of litter comes from takeout and convenience items. Respecting our shared spaces is just basic consideration for others, and good policy should reinforce that.

As someone who’s spent a lifetime trying to teach young people to respect their surroundings, I believe the best way to prevent littering is a combination of education, convenient infrastructure, and fair enforcement. We should invest in more visible trash and recycling bins, community clean‑up days, and school programs that teach environmental responsibility from an early age, along with reasonable fines when people repeatedly ignore the rules. I’d also like to see local governments partner with charities and community groups, so caring for our shared spaces feels like a neighborly duty, not just a law on the books.

Where I’m from, we’re taught to take pride in our community and not leave our mess for someone else to deal with, so I think strong personal responsibility and respect for shared spaces should come first. That said, I’m all for tougher fines, clear signage, and plenty of trash and recycling bins in parks, parking lots, and along highways to make it easy to do the right thing and costly to do the wrong one.

If people can’t respect shared spaces on their own, then there need to be real consequences for littering—heavy fines and actually enforcing them. I’d also like to see more trash and recycling bins in parks, at playgrounds, and around workplaces so there’s no excuse to toss stuff on the ground. Teaching kids early, at school and at home, to clean up after themselves is just as important, because personal responsibility starts young. Public spaces belong to all of us, and keeping them clean shouldn’t be someone else’s job.

I think the best way to cut down on litter is to make personal responsibility the norm again, backed up with real, consistently enforced fines. Cities and towns should provide enough trash cans and dumpsters, especially in busy areas and parks, but people need to be held accountable when they just toss garbage on the ground. I’d also like to see more community clean‑up days and school programs that teach kids pride in their town so they grow up respecting shared spaces instead of expecting the government to pick up after them.

I think the best way to stop littering is to teach people to take pride in their communities, starting with schools, churches, and local groups reminding folks that caring for God’s creation is a personal responsibility. We should have clear rules and real fines for littering, but also provide enough trash cans and recycling bins so there’s no excuse. I’d support community clean-up days and programs where people who litter have to help clean public spaces, so they see the impact of their actions.

As a teacher and a mom, I see how much our environment shapes kids’ attitudes, so I think the best way to prevent littering is a combination of education and clear accountability. Schools and cities should partner on hands-on environmental programs, frequent community cleanups, and age-appropriate lessons about where trash goes and why it matters, paired with visible trash and recycling bins and meaningful fines for repeat offenders. When children grow up seeing clean public spaces, strong community norms, and consistent enforcement, not only do they litter less, they grow into adults who expect and protect clean neighborhoods.

Working in veterinary care, I see firsthand how litter harms animals—everything from wildlife getting tangled in plastic to pets ingesting trash—so I’m strongly in favor of strict anti-littering policies. The best approach combines clear fines and consistent enforcement with plenty of visible trash and recycling bins, plus public education that emphasizes how litter impacts local ecosystems and animal welfare. I’d also support community clean-up days and programs that hold businesses responsible for managing the waste their products generate, because preventing litter should be a shared responsibility, not just an individual one.

I think the best way to stop littering is to make it really easy for people to throw things away, like having lots of trash and recycling bins that are actually emptied and not overflowing. Schools and communities should also do fun projects, like clean-up days and posters designed by kids, so people feel kind of embarrassed to leave trash around. I don’t have a lot of money, but I know fines can work too, especially if people see others getting in trouble for littering. When parks and streets look clean, it makes me want to keep them that way, not mess them up.

Look, I spend most of my life on the road, and there’s nothing that ticks me off more than seeing our highways and rest stops covered in trash. I don’t think we need a bunch of new big-government programs, but we *do* need real fines that are actually enforced, plus plenty of trash cans and dumpsters where folks can easily use them. I’d rather see businesses, local communities, and even trucking companies step up with clean-up efforts and “adopt-a-highway” type programs than rely on Washington to fix it. Personal responsibility ought to come first: you pack it in, you pack it out—no excuses.

As someone who spends a lot of time outside with my kids, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of personal responsibility and practical policies—more trash and recycling bins where people actually are, and real fines for those who still throw garbage on the ground. Public campaigns that speak to family values and pride in our neighborhoods, especially in both English and Spanish, would also help remind people that keeping our streets clean is about respecting each other and the place we all share.

At my age, I’ve seen how a community’s character shows up on its sidewalks and in its parks, and it breaks my heart to see them littered. The most effective policies combine strict enforcement—fines, visible trash and recycling bins, and regular clean-up crews—with education that starts in schools and continues through public campaigns, so people understand their shared responsibility. I also believe cities should invest in attractive, well-maintained public spaces, because when places feel cared for, people are less likely to treat them like a dumping ground.

As someone who grew up believing in personal responsibility and still walks my neighborhood every day, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of strict enforcement and clear consequences alongside community pride. We should have visible trash and recycling bins, meaningful fines for those who litter, and school and church-based education that teaches respect for shared spaces as a moral and civic duty. Public-private partnerships—businesses sponsoring clean-up efforts or maintaining areas near their locations—can also reinforce that keeping our streets clean is everyone’s job, not just the government’s.

As someone who spends a lot of time outdoors and walking lots and car lots, I notice how much trash ends up on the ground, and it really bothers me. I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of strong enforcement—clear fines that are actually applied—and making it easy to do the right thing by putting out more trash and recycling bins and keeping them well maintained. We should also invest in community clean-up programs and education, especially in neighborhoods that have been overlooked, so people feel a sense of pride and ownership in their public spaces. When folks see their community cared for, they’re less likely to treat it like a dumping ground.

I think the best way to cut down on litter is a mix of personal responsibility and tough, consistently enforced penalties. Cities and counties should provide enough trash and recycling bins and keep them emptied, but people need to be held accountable with real fines and community service when they toss garbage on the ground. Schools, churches, and local groups can reinforce the message that taking care of our shared spaces is part of being a good neighbor and good steward of what God’s given us.

I’m too little to make rules, but when I go to the park with my family, I don’t like seeing trash on the ground where I play. Grown‑ups should put out lots of bright trash and recycling bins, teach kids at church and school to take care of God’s creation, and make sure people help clean up if they litter. That way the places where we run and giggle stay clean and safe for everyone.

As someone who spends a lot of time outdoors with my family, I think strong anti-littering policies really matter—not just fines, but making it easy for people to do the right thing. That means more trash and recycling bins in parks, on sidewalks, and at bus stops, plus clear signage and public campaigns that teach kids early on to respect shared spaces. I’d also support community clean‑up programs and holding businesses accountable for excess packaging and waste, since big companies contribute a lot to what ends up on our streets.

As someone who’s spent his career in law enforcement, I’ve seen firsthand how small things like littering add up to bigger problems in a community. The best way to prevent it is a mix of firm enforcement—clear fines that are actually applied—combined with practical solutions like enough trash cans, regular cleanup, and holding businesses and event organizers accountable for their mess. Public education helps, but people respond most when there are real consequences and visible standards. Keeping our streets and parks clean is about personal responsibility and respect for our neighbors and the place we call home.

At my age, I’ve seen that the most effective way to prevent littering is a mix of clear rules and shared responsibility. We should have strong, consistently enforced fines, but also invest in plentiful trash and recycling bins, public art and beautification projects, and school programs that teach kids to respect common spaces. As someone who loves to paint and walk in quiet parks, I think clean public spaces are a kind of living canvas we all share—and government, businesses, and citizens should each do their part to keep them that way.

As someone who spends his days caring for people’s health, I see clean public spaces as a basic public health and dignity issue, not just an aesthetic one. The best policies to prevent littering combine practical measures—like plentiful trash and recycling bins, clear signage, and consistent fines—with education that appeals to our shared responsibility for one another and for the environment. I’d like to see community service, rather than just monetary penalties, for repeat offenders, so people directly experience the impact of their actions. Public campaigns that highlight how litter disproportionately harms poorer neighborhoods also align with my belief in social justice and our moral duty to protect the most vulnerable.

As someone raising kids and trying to finish school, I really care what our streets, parks, and especially our land look like, because it’s the place my kids are growing up and it’s sacred to us as Navajo. I think there should be more garbage and recycling bins, real fines that are actually enforced, and community clean-up programs that include youth so people learn early not to trash our shared spaces. Schools should teach about how littering hurts the environment and our health, and cities should invest in cleaner infrastructure instead of just blaming individuals. Respecting the land means taking responsibility for what we throw away, and policy should make it easier to do the right thing than the lazy thing.

As someone who spends a lot of time in parks and public areas with my kids, I think strong anti-littering policies are important, but they only work if cities also give people enough trash and recycling bins and pick up the garbage regularly. We should have real fines for littering, especially for big businesses that create a lot of waste, but we also need education in schools and community campaigns in Spanish and English so everyone understands why keeping our shared spaces clean matters. I’d also support programs that pay or reward people—especially youth—for neighborhood cleanups, because protecting our environment and public spaces should be a shared responsibility, not just an individual one.

As someone who spends a lot of time outdoors with my family and cares deeply about conservation, I think the most effective way to prevent littering is a mix of clear, well-enforced regulations and constant, visible education. We should pair substantial fines and adequate trash/recycling infrastructure with school- and community-based programs that teach people, especially kids, how their everyday choices affect local wildlife and ecosystems. Public institutions like colleges and universities ought to lead by example, maintaining clean campuses, organizing regular clean-up events, and making it socially unacceptable to leave trash behind.

As someone who works in telecommunications and spends a lot of time in different neighborhoods and public spaces, I see firsthand how much litter can pile up when there aren’t enough trash and recycling bins or when they’re not maintained. I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of practical infrastructure—more accessible, clearly labeled bins—strong but fair enforcement of fines, and community-based programs like clean-up days and school education so people feel responsible for shared spaces. Public campaigns that connect cleanliness to community pride and environmental health, especially in lower-income or underserved areas, are important, and funds from fines should go straight back into local clean-up and green projects.

When we go to the park or the beach, I feel sad when I see trash on the ground instead of in the bin, because it makes the place look ugly and can hurt animals. I think there should be more trash and recycling cans everywhere, with big pictures and colors so kids like me know where to put things, and grown‑ups should have to pay a fine if they litter on purpose. If teachers and parents show us how to clean up together and explain why it matters, more people will want to keep our places nice and clean.

At 94, I’ve watched our public spaces become increasingly choked with trash, and it pains me when I’m out bird watching or tending my small garden plots in the community. The best way to prevent littering is a mix of firm policy and shared responsibility: clear bans with real fines, plenty of well‑maintained bins and recycling stations, and public education that starts in schools. I’m comfortable paying a bit more in local taxes if it funds robust sanitation crews and community clean‑ups, because keeping our parks and streets clean is a basic public good, not just a matter of individual virtue.

When I go on walks or play outside, it makes me sad to see trash on the ground because it hurts animals and makes nature less pretty. I think there should be more trash and recycling bins in parks and on sidewalks, and grown-ups should teach kids at school and at home why we should always throw our trash away. People who litter on purpose should have to help clean up parks so they understand how much work it takes to keep the earth clean.

I don’t like seeing trash on the ground at the park because it makes it yucky to play and I worry the animals might get hurt. I think grown-ups should put more trash cans around and teach people, even little kids like me, to always throw things away and help clean up together.

As someone who spends her days teaching little ones about kindness and responsibility, I think the best way to prevent littering is to combine strong public education with clear accountability. We should have well-placed trash and recycling bins, visible fines that are actually enforced, and school-based programs that get kids (and their parents) thinking about caring for our shared spaces. I’m a big believer that when communities invest in clean, safe parks and sidewalks—especially in family neighborhoods—people feel more ownership and are less likely to trash them.

I think the best way to prevent littering in public spaces is to combine strict enforcement with education, especially in schools, so people grow up understanding how their actions affect their community and the environment. Cities should provide plenty of trash and recycling bins, and businesses—like the restaurant where I work—should be required to reduce waste and encourage customers to clean up after themselves. Public campaigns that make it “cool” to care about clean neighborhoods, along with fines for people who keep littering, would help send the message that everyone has a responsibility to keep our shared spaces clean.

As someone who spends a lot of time in parks and public spaces with my bebé, it really frustrates me to see litter everywhere—our kids deserve clean places to play. I think we need a mix of stronger fines and consistent enforcement, plus way more trash and recycling bins and community education, especially in both English and Spanish so everyone feels included. I’d also love to see schools and local churches organize regular cleanup days and make it feel like a shared responsibility—cuando todos ponemos de nuestra parte, our neighborhoods stay beautiful and healthy.

As someone who works in restaurants and sees firsthand how much waste we generate, I think strong anti-littering policies need to be paired with better infrastructure and education, not just fines. Cities should invest in more public trash and recycling bins, require businesses to use eco-friendly packaging, and run awareness campaigns about how litter affects local communities and the environment. I’m pretty social and out in public a lot, and it’s obvious that when spaces are clean and bins are easy to find, people are more likely to do the right thing.

I think the best way to stop littering is to put more trash and recycling cans everywhere and make it easy for people to throw stuff away. At my church and school, when adults explain *why* keeping places clean matters and kids help with clean-up days, people litter less because they feel responsible. There should also be signs that remind people that God wants us to take care of the earth and maybe small fines for people who litter on purpose.

Para mí, prevenir la basura en los espacios públicos empieza con la educación y el respeto: enseñar desde la casa, la iglesia y la escuela que cuidar la calle es cuidar nuestro hogar y honrar a Dios y al prójimo. También creo que el gobierno local debería poner suficientes botes de basura y reciclaje, y aplicar multas razonables a quien tire basura, para que la gente se lo piense dos veces.

As someone who takes pride in her community and enjoys walking through clean parks and neighborhoods, I believe the best way to prevent littering is a mix of personal responsibility and firm consequences. We should have clear laws with meaningful fines for littering, plenty of trash and recycling bins, and local volunteer clean-up efforts through churches and civic groups to reinforce shared values of respect and stewardship.

As someone who takes pride in my home and neighborhood, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of personal responsibility, strict enforcement, and community standards. We should have clear laws with real fines for littering, plenty of trash and recycling bins in public areas, and local campaigns through churches, schools, and community groups that teach respect for shared spaces. When people see their neighbors and local businesses keeping things clean, it sets a standard that littering just isn’t acceptable.

Public spaces stay clean when people take personal responsibility and face real consequences if they don’t. I support stricter fines for littering, more trash and recycling bins where they’re actually needed, and enforcement that’s consistent instead of just for show. Cities shouldn’t have to waste extra tax money cleaning up after people who can’t be bothered to use a garbage can. If we want to enjoy parks, sidewalks, and neighborhoods that feel cared for, everyone needs to do their part instead of expecting the government to pick up after them.

Growing up and living in Michigan, I’ve seen how litter sends a message that a community isn’t valued, and that hits especially hard in Black neighborhoods that have already been ignored for too long. The best policies to prevent littering combine strict enforcement and plenty of trash and recycling bins with real investment in public education, youth jobs, and community cleanups so people feel ownership of their streets and parks. I’d also like to see corporations held accountable for excessive packaging and required to help fund cleanup efforts, because responsibility shouldn’t fall only on working folks and volunteers.

I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of personal responsibility and practical solutions, like more clearly marked trash and recycling bins in parks and shopping areas. I’d also support stricter fines for people who litter, because it’s not fair for taxpayers and volunteers to constantly clean up after others. Community clean‑up days and school programs can help teach kids and families to take pride in keeping our neighborhoods and outdoor spaces clean for everyone, including our grandkids.

As someone who works in healthcare and sees every day how environment affects public health, I believe strong anti-littering policies need to combine clear enforcement with easy access to trash and recycling bins in every public space. We should pair fines for littering with community education, school programs, and volunteer clean-up efforts so people—especially kids—feel a shared responsibility for their neighborhoods. I’d also support city-funded campaigns and partnerships with local nonprofits that make it simple and convenient to dispose of waste properly, because relying on personal responsibility alone clearly isn’t enough.

As someone who spends a lot of time walking around cities, reading on park benches, and noticing the small details of public spaces, litter feels like a quiet vandalism of places that should belong to all of us. The best policies mix strong, consistently enforced fines with simple infrastructure—ample trash and recycling bins, clear signage, and well-maintained spaces—because people are more likely to respect an environment that already looks cared for. I’d also love to see creative public campaigns that tap into shame and pride—think vivid messaging, art, and social norms nudges—rather than just scolding, especially in schools and community programs. In the end, preventing litter is about treating shared spaces with the same respect we’d give to a friend’s living room.

As someone who spends a lot of time in community gardens and public areas, I think the best way to prevent littering is to invest in more trash and recycling bins, regular cleaning, and clear, visual signs in languages people actually speak, like Spanish and English. But just rules and fines aren’t enough—we need community education in schools and neighborhoods, and to involve local residents in clean-up days so people feel proud and responsible for the spaces we share.

As a father and a public employee, I think the best way to prevent littering is to combine clear rules with personal responsibility and community pride. We should enforce existing anti-littering laws with real fines, but also make it easier for people to do the right thing by providing enough trash and recycling bins in parks, downtown areas, and around schools and churches. Local schools, parishes, and community groups can teach kids and adults alike to respect our shared spaces and local history, so people see keeping our town clean as part of their duty, not just a rule to follow.

Working in a school, I see every day how much cleaner and safer a place feels when everyone takes responsibility for their trash, so I think strong anti-littering policies matter. We need more trash and recycling bins in public spaces, clear signs, and real fines that are actually enforced, but we also need to teach kids early—at school and at home—about respecting our communities and the people who clean them. I’d like to see cities invest in community clean-up programs and jobs too, so keeping our neighborhoods clean is something we do together, not just something we punish after the fact.

As someone who cares deeply about both my neighborhood and the environment, I think the best way to prevent littering is a combination of strict enforcement and thoughtful design. We should have plenty of conveniently placed recycling and trash bins, clear signage about fines, and consistent ticketing for offenders, but also invest in community clean‑up days and school education so people feel ownership of their public spaces. When residents are involved—through volunteer programs, local business sponsorships, and visible city support—they’re far less likely to treat parks, sidewalks, and streets like disposable areas.

I think the best way to prevent littering is to teach people, especially kids, *why* it matters—like showing how trash hurts animals and makes our neighborhoods uglier and less healthy. Schools, churches, and libraries could work together on clean‑up days and projects so we actually feel responsible for our own parks and streets. There should still be clear rules and fines for people who litter on purpose, but if there are plenty of trash and recycling bins and people are educated, a lot of littering would probably stop before it happens.

At my age, I’ve seen how much a community’s pride shows in how clean we keep our streets and parks, and I think we need a mix of strong rules and steady education to protect them. Clear fines for littering, plenty of visible trash and recycling bins, and school and community programs that teach respect for shared spaces—ideally with signs and materials that are accessible to people with disabilities—would all help. I’d also like to see more local volunteers, like we have at our community center, organizing clean-up days so people feel personally responsible for the places we all share.

As someone who spends a lot of time outdoors hiking and gardening, it drives me nuts to see trails and parks covered in trash—it shows zero respect for shared spaces. I support stricter fines and real enforcement for littering, but that has to be paired with plenty of visible trash and recycling bins, bottle return programs, and public education that starts in schools. I’d also like to see businesses held responsible for excessive packaging and required to help fund cleanup and waste-reduction efforts, since they’re a big part of what ends up on the ground.

As someone who spends a lot of time walking across campus and reading in public spaces, I think the most effective way to prevent littering is a mix of smart design and shared responsibility: plentiful, clearly labeled trash and recycling bins, regular maintenance, and visible norms that make clean spaces feel like the standard, not the exception. Fines and enforcement have their place, but I’d rather see schools and cities invest in education campaigns, student-led initiatives, and community clean-ups that help people feel collectively responsible for the spaces we use together.

As someone who cares deeply about our town’s history and natural beauty, I believe preventing littering starts with personal responsibility, not more bureaucracy. We should enforce existing laws with real fines, provide enough trash and recycling bins in parks and downtown, and organize neighborhood clean-up days through churches and civic groups to build pride in our community. I’d also like to see schools and local groups teach kids respect for shared spaces so they grow up understanding that keeping our streets and parks clean is everyone’s job.

As someone who spends a lot of time in well-kept office districts and busy family spaces, I think the most effective way to prevent littering is a mix of clear rules, visible enforcement, and well-designed infrastructure—enough trash and recycling bins, frequent pickups, and real fines that are actually applied. We should also invest in public education, especially for kids, that frames not littering as a basic civic and environmental responsibility, the same way we teach seatbelt use. When people see clean, well-maintained spaces, they’re more likely to respect them, and policy should be built around reinforcing that norm.

As a teacher, a mom, and someone who loves spending time outdoors, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of strong public policy and early education. Cities should provide ample trash and recycling bins, enforce meaningful fines for littering, and invest in public awareness campaigns, especially in schools, so kids grow up seeing clean public spaces as a shared responsibility. I’d also support community clean-up events and partnerships with local organizations, because when people feel ownership of their parks and streets, they’re much less likely to treat them like a dumping ground.

As someone who spends a lot of quiet time outdoors in my garden and around my neighborhood, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of clear rules, visible trash and recycling bins, and consistent fines that are actually enforced. But policy alone isn’t enough—we should also invest in public education, especially with kids and in community programs, to build a culture where people feel responsible for shared spaces. I’d also support “adopt-a-park” or “adopt-a-street” volunteer programs so residents have a real sense of ownership and pride in keeping areas clean.

At my age, I’ve watched our towns change, and it bothers me to see parks and sidewalks cluttered with trash when it’s not that hard to use a bin. I think we need a mix of strict fines for littering, plenty of clearly marked trash and recycling cans, and regular public clean-up efforts supported by local government. Education matters too—reminders in schools, on TV, and on signs that caring for shared spaces is part of being a decent neighbor. I may live alone and keep to myself, but I still believe we have a responsibility to each other to keep our communities clean and welcoming.

As someone who spends a lot of time in parks, streets, and venues performing, I see litter as a sign that we’ve stopped feeling connected to the spaces we share. The most effective policies, in my view, combine strict enforcement and real penalties with practical tools—plenty of visible bins, bottle-deposit systems, and clear signage—plus arts-driven public campaigns that make caring for our environment feel like a shared, creative responsibility. I’d also support requiring event organizers and businesses to have litter plans and clean-up accountability, so the burden doesn’t just fall on underfunded city crews. When people see that public spaces are treated with respect and beauty, they’re far less likely to trash them.

Working in a nursing facility and spending a lot of time in my garden, I see every day how a clean environment affects people’s health, dignity, and mood. I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of strong accountability—fines that are actually enforced—and making it easy to do the right thing with plenty of well-maintained trash and recycling bins. We also need community-based education, especially in lower-income and historically neglected neighborhoods, so people feel ownership of their public spaces instead of feeling like no one cares. For me, keeping our streets clean is not just about appearances; it’s about respect, justice, and caring for one another’s health.

As a teacher and an active member of my community, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of smart policy and strong education. We should invest in plenty of well-maintained trash and recycling bins, enforce fines for repeat offenders, and pair that with school and community programs that teach respect for shared spaces and the environment from an early age. Public campaigns that tap into local culture—like music events that highlight sustainability—can also help make keeping our streets clean feel like a shared community value, not just a rule.

As someone who spends a lot of time outdoors gardening and going to community wellness events, I find litter really undermines both our health and our shared public spaces. The most effective policies combine strong, consistently enforced fines with practical solutions like plenty of well‑placed trash and recycling bins, bottle-deposit programs, and funded clean-up crews. I’d also like to see public education campaigns, especially in schools and neighborhoods, that frame keeping spaces clean as a shared civic and environmental responsibility rather than just a rule to follow.

As someone who spends a lot of time outdoors with my family, it really frustrates me to see parks, roadsides, and trails covered in trash. I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of tough enforcement with real fines, plenty of convenient trash and recycling bins, and community clean-up days that get people—especially kids—personally invested in keeping our spaces clean. Local governments and businesses should work together on clear signage and consistent penalties so people know littering isn’t just rude, it actually has consequences. Keeping our public spaces clean is about responsibility and respect—for our communities, our kids, and God’s creation.

As a teacher and a dad, I want my kids and students to grow up in clean, respectful communities, so I believe the best way to prevent littering is through personal responsibility backed by firm, consistently enforced penalties. Clear rules, visible trash and recycling bins, and meaningful fines for offenders send the message that public spaces belong to all of us and must be cared for. Schools and churches can also play a big role by teaching kids early that taking care of our environment is part of being a good neighbor and a good steward of what God has given us.

As a public school teacher and someone who spends a lot of time in parks and community spaces, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of smart policy and education. Cities should invest in plenty of well-placed trash and recycling bins, enforce fines fairly but consistently, and pair that with school-based and community programs that teach kids and adults why keeping shared spaces clean matters. I’d also support local “adopt-a-park” style initiatives and volunteer cleanups that give people a sense of ownership and pride in their neighborhoods, because when communities feel connected to a place, they’re less likely to trash it.

As a teacher and someone who spends a lot of time outdoors bird watching and gardening, I think strong anti-littering policies have to combine clear enforcement with real education. We should have visible fines and plenty of trash and recycling bins, but also school- and community-based programs that teach how litter harms local ecosystems and wildlife. I’d also support city-funded cleanup and beautification projects, because when neighborhoods are cared for and attractive, people are less likely to treat them like dumping grounds.

Honestly, if we’re serious about stopping littering, we need more than just a few sad trash cans and “please don’t litter” signs. We should have strict fines that are actually enforced, way more accessible bins and recycling options on every block and trail, and mandatory community clean‑up days so people see the impact of their trash. Schools and local churches could team up to teach environmental responsibility early on, tying it to faith and ethics as well as science. When people feel connected to their environment and held accountable, they’re way less likely to treat public spaces like a dumping ground.

As a mom and someone who cares a lot about keeping our community clean and safe for our kids, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of personal responsibility, education, and some real consequences when people don’t do the right thing. We should have plenty of trash and recycling bins, clear signs, and school and community programs that teach kids and adults why it matters, but also enforce fines for littering so people take it seriously.

As a mom raising young kids, I want our parks and streets to be clean and safe, and I don’t think that happens just by hoping people do the right thing. We should have more visible trash and recycling bins, clear signage, and firm fines that are actually enforced for littering. I also believe in personal responsibility, so schools, churches, and community groups should teach respect for shared spaces and organize clean-up events so kids grow up seeing that caring for our environment is just part of being a good neighbor.

As someone who spends a lot of time thinking about health, both physical and communal, I see littering as a social justice issue: trash doesn’t just make neighborhoods ugly, it disproportionately harms poorer and marginalized communities. The best policies combine strong public investment in frequent trash and recycling pickup, plenty of clearly marked bins, and meaningful fines for repeat offenders, alongside community education that frames clean public spaces as a shared responsibility. I’d also support programs that pay or incentivize local residents—especially those struggling with employment—to help with cleanup and environmental stewardship, so the benefits and the work are distributed more fairly.

As someone who cares a lot about how our shared spaces look and feel, I think the most effective anti-litter policies combine smart design, convenience, and accountability: plenty of well-placed bins and recycling options, clear signage, and regular, visible cleanup so people see that the space is valued. I also support modest fines for littering that are actually enforced, paired with public education campaigns—especially creative, eye-catching ones—because changing the culture around waste is just as important as the rules themselves.

As someone who spends a lot of time gardening, walking in my neighborhood, and volunteering in the community, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of clear rules and strong local involvement. We should have visible trash and recycling bins, meaningful fines that are actually enforced, and school and community programs that teach respect for shared spaces. I also believe in organizing volunteer clean-up events and public campaigns that appeal to people’s sense of responsibility and care for the environment, rather than just scolding them. When people feel ownership of their parks and sidewalks, they’re much less likely to toss trash on the ground.

Living simply, I try to respect the spaces we all share, and my faith teaches me that the earth is a trust from God, not something to trash. The best way to prevent littering is a mix of clear rules and real support: plenty of trash and recycling bins, regular cleanup crews, and fines that are actually enforced but not so harsh they fall hardest on poor folks. I also think community education—especially in schools and through local groups and mosques—can build a sense of responsibility and dignity around keeping our neighborhoods clean. Public spaces should feel cared for by everyone, not just cleaned up by a few.

As someone who cares about keeping my community clean and spends a lot of time outside and at the gym, I think we need a mix of personal responsibility and firm consequences to cut down on littering. Clear rules, more trash and recycling bins, and strict fines that are actually enforced would send the message that public spaces aren’t anyone’s dumping ground. I also believe families and churches should teach kids early on to respect shared spaces, because that kind of value sticks longer than any government program.

As someone who believes we’re called to be good stewards of God’s creation, I think strong anti-littering laws with real fines are important, but they’re not enough on their own. We need to teach children and adults alike—through schools, churches, and community programs—that caring for our neighborhoods is a moral responsibility, not just a legal one. Public trash and recycling bins should be easy to find and well-maintained so people have no excuse to toss garbage on the ground. Ultimately, building a culture of personal responsibility and respect for shared spaces will do more than any slogan or campaign alone.

As a mom and someone who spends a lot of time outdoors and in my garden, I care a lot about keeping public spaces clean and healthy for our kids and the environment. I think the best way to prevent littering is a combination of practical measures—like plenty of clearly marked trash and recycling bins, regular clean-up efforts, and visible fines for littering—along with education in schools and communities about why it matters. I’m not big on heavy-handed rules, but I do think people are more likely to do the right thing when it’s easy and when they understand the impact of their actions. Public campaigns that show local consequences, like trash in nearby parks or waterways, would really help make it feel more real to people.

As someone who spends a lot of time outdoors gardening, walking, and doing yoga in public parks, I’m frankly fed up with how casually people treat shared spaces as trash cans. The most effective way to prevent littering is a mix of stronger enforcement with real fines, plenty of clearly marked bins and recycling options, and ongoing public education that starts in schools and is reinforced through community campaigns. I’m willing to pay a bit more in local taxes for cleaner, safer, more beautiful public areas, and I’d also support corporate accountability measures so businesses reduce single-use packaging that ends up on our streets in the first place.

If you want people to stop littering, you hit them in the wallet and make it easy to do the right thing. I’m all for stiff fines and actually enforcing them, plus putting more trash and recycling bins where folks actually walk so there’s no excuse. I don’t want another bloated government program, just clear rules, personal responsibility, and maybe private companies contracted to keep high-traffic areas clean. My kids should be able to play in parks that aren’t covered in fast-food bags and beer cans, and that comes down to holding individuals accountable, not preaching at them.

At my age, having watched this country change over many decades, I’m convinced the best way to prevent littering is to reinforce personal responsibility and respect for shared spaces, not just pass new regulations. Clear, consistently enforced fines, plenty of well-placed trash and recycling bins, and community service requirements for offenders would help, but we also need schools, churches, and local civic groups to teach younger generations that caring for our streets and parks is simply part of good citizenship and moral duty.

I don’t like when I see trash on the ground at the park because it makes it look yucky and I can’t play there nice. Grown-ups should put more trash cans everywhere, and they should tell people “no littering” a lot and give them tickets if they throw trash. At church and at school, they can teach us that God wants us to take care of the world, so we learn to always put garbage in the bin.

I was raised to believe you pick up after yourself and respect shared spaces, and I still think personal responsibility is the most important part of stopping litter. We should have clear rules, plenty of trash and recycling cans, and real fines that are actually enforced for people who choose to litter anyway. Schools and churches can help teach younger generations that caring for the environment starts with small, everyday actions like not throwing garbage on the ground.

Look, I grew up in New York, I’ve seen what happens when people think the sidewalk is their trash can, and it drives me nuts. If we’re serious about stopping litter, we need a mix of things: lots of visible cans and recycling bins, real fines that are actually enforced, and public education that starts young and keeps going. I’m liberal, sure, but I’ve got no patience for folks who treat shared spaces like a dump—cities should invest in cleaner infrastructure and community cleanup programs, and people who trash the place should pay for it, plain and simple.

As someone who spends a lot of time outdoors gardening and cares about my community, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of strict enforcement and smart design—meaning plenty of visible trash and recycling bins, clear signage, and real fines that are actually enforced. We should also invest in public education, especially for kids, about how litter harms our environment and neighborhoods, and hold corporations accountable for excessive single-use packaging that ends up on our streets.

Working in restaurants and bars, I see firsthand how much trash people generate without thinking, so I really believe in a mix of strict rules and making it easy to do the right thing. Cities should invest in plenty of clearly marked trash and recycling bins, regular cleanup crews, and public education, but also actually enforce fines for littering so it’s not just a suggestion. I’d also support policies that push businesses—especially takeout and fast-food places—to use less single-use packaging and help fund cleanup efforts. Keeping public spaces clean is a basic respect issue for the community, and government should take the lead instead of leaving it all to volunteers.

Back in my day, folks took more personal responsibility for keeping their towns clean, and I still believe that’s the foundation of preventing littering. The best policies are a mix of strict enforcement with real fines, plenty of clearly marked trash and recycling bins, and community-based efforts like church and neighborhood clean-up days that teach respect for shared spaces. I’d also like to see schools and local groups emphasize stewardship of God’s creation, so people see not littering as a moral obligation, not just a rule.

As someone who spends a lot of time out on the road and in different neighborhoods for work, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of personal responsibility and smart incentives. Clear rules with meaningful fines should be enforced consistently, but we should also make it easy to do the right thing by having plenty of well-placed trash and recycling bins and community clean-up programs that families can join. I’d rather see local, community-driven solutions and education—especially for kids—than heavy-handed federal mandates. In the long run, if people understand the impact on their own towns and take pride in them, you need fewer laws to keep public spaces clean.

As someone who cares deeply about my neighborhood and spends a lot of time in parks and community spaces with my kids, I believe strong anti-littering policies need to combine clear rules with real community buy-in. That means adequate trash and recycling bins, fines that are actually enforced, and school- and faith-based education that teaches respect for shared spaces as a moral responsibility. I’d also like to see partnerships with local nonprofits and volunteer groups to organize regular cleanups and public art or signage that reinforces pride in our community. When people feel ownership of their environment and see that it’s well-maintained, they’re far less likely to litter in the first place.

As someone who works in a medical office and sees every day how much waste we generate, I think strong anti-littering policies are essential—both for public health and for the example we set for our kids. We should combine real enforcement and meaningful fines with plenty of trash and recycling bins, clear signage, and school-based education so children grow up understanding their responsibility to shared spaces. I’m also in favor of things like bottle-deposit programs and holding companies accountable for excess packaging, because individuals shouldn’t shoulder the blame for a system that encourages disposability.

Working in sound recording, I spend a lot of time thinking about how environments affect people’s experiences, and littered public spaces just kill the vibe of a community. I’d support a mix of strong, consistently enforced fines, plenty of well-placed recycling and trash bins, and public education campaigns—especially creative, arts-focused ones—to shift norms around waste. Cities should also fund community cleanup events and partner with local artists and venues, because when people feel real ownership of their parks and streets, they’re much less likely to trash them.

When I go to the park, I like when the grass is clean so I can run and find my toys without stepping on yucky stuff. Grown-ups should put lots of trash cans everywhere and show everyone, even little kids like me, how to throw trash away and clean up together.

As someone who manages construction sites for a living, I’ve seen firsthand how much cleaner and safer a place stays when there are clear rules, visible trash and recycling bins, and real consequences for ignoring them. I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of strict enforcement with fines, public education that emphasizes personal responsibility and respect for shared spaces, and requiring businesses and event organizers to maintain clean areas. When everyone treats public spaces like they’re their own property, the whole community benefits.

As a public school teacher and a Catholic who believes we’re called to be good stewards of creation, I think strong, practical policies are the best way to tackle littering. That means plenty of clearly marked trash and recycling bins, regular cleanups funded by local government, and consistent fines that are actually enforced. Just as important, though, is making anti-littering part of school curriculum so kids grow up understanding their responsibility to keep our shared spaces clean.

As someone who cares about both my neighborhood and how we use technology, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of clear rules, smart design, and consistent enforcement. Cities should invest in more visible, well-placed trash and recycling bins, use data and sensors to track where littering is worst, and pair fines with public education campaigns in schools and online. I’d also like to see “smart” incentives—like apps that reward people for reporting full bins or participating in clean-up events—so it feels easy and rewarding to do the right thing.
